title-group.article-title: Association between neutrophil-to-high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol ratio and prevalence and mortality of diabetes: a cross-sectional study

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Endocrinology and Metabolism, Chengdu Seventh People’s Hospital, Chengdu, China

3Department of Nephrology, Chengdu Seventh People’s Hospital, Chengdu, China

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Inflammatory responses and lipid metabolism play critical roles in diabetes development. This study explored the association between the neutrophil-to-high-density lipoprotein cholesterol ratio (NHR) and diabetes prevalence and mortality.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This cross-sectional study was conducted in the National Health and Nutrition Survey (NHANES) from 1999 to 2018. The correlation between NHR and the prevalence of diabetes was evaluated using logistic regression models. Additionally, the Cox proportional hazards model was applied to investigate whether NHR related to the risk of mortality from all causes and cardiovascular diseases. A series of sensitivity analyses and subgroup analyses were performed to test the robustness of the findings.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Among the 52,428 study participants, 8,114 (15.48%) had diabetes, with a mean neutrophil-to-high-density lipoprotein cholesterol ratio (NHR) of 3.49. In the full-adjusted model, each unit increase in NHR was related to a 17.0% higher risk of diabetes (odds ratio, 1.17 [95% CI 1.13–1.21], P < 0.001). Results were similar when participants were categorized by NHR tertiles (odds ratio, 2.08 [95% CI 1.76–2.47], comparing extreme quartiles). The stratified analyses showed that the association between NHR and risk of diabetes was more obvious in female, White, former smokers and participants with age ≥ 50 years. After a median (interquartile range) follow-up of 9.42 (5.08–14.33) years, higher NHR levels were positively associated with the risk of all-cause and cardiovascular disease mortality in diabetes patients. A series of sensitivity analyses confirmed the robustness of the findings.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Elevated NHR is linked to higher diabetes prevalence and increased mortality risk in a U.S. population, independent of traditional risk factors. Regular monitoring of NHR may serve as an easy-to-measure tool for risk stratification for diabetes and its adverse outcomes.

sec.title: Clinical trial number
sec.p: Not applicable.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at10.1186/s12902-025-01978-1.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Diabetes mellitus is currently at an unimaginable level of prevalence, with an estimated 439 million adult diabetes patients by 2030, of which over 90% are type 2 diabetes mellitus [1]. Diabetes-related medical costs are estimated to be approximately $327 billion annually, which imposes a significant financial impact on families and society [1, 2]. Individuals with diabetes have an increased risk of macrovascular and microvascular complications, including cardiovascular disease (CVD), nephropathy, retinopathy and neuropathy, but complications often arise too late and lack reliable treatments at that time [3]. Thus, early identification and timely management of risk factors are crucial to reduce the significant burden of mortality and disability associated with diabetes.

In addition to blood glucose changes, inflammatory response and abnormal lipid metabolism are critical in causing and developing diabetes [4–6]. As an important component of the innate immune system, neutrophils play a central role in fighting infections and have been shown to be correlated with disease severity [7]. Recently, higher neutrophils were confirmed to be related to higher glycemia and elevated glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels, and further to increase the risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in patients with diabetes [8, 9]. In addition, researchers have pointed out that lipid traits, especially high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) levels, can be used to predict the occurrence and progression of diabetes. Increasing HDL-C levels were usually accompanied by effective blood glucose control in patients with diabetes [10, 11]. Furthermore, previous studies indicated that activated neutrophils could not only have an impact on the composition and function of HDL-C [12], but its function could also be regulated by HDL-C [13]. In recent years, the neutrophil-to-high-density lipoprotein cholesterol ratio (NHR) has been proposed as a comprehensive indicator of inflammation and lipid metabolic status, providing insights into their combined effects on disease development. Its measurement is simple, affordable, and standardized, positioning NHR as a potential clinical tool [14, 15]. Research suggests that NHR is superior to the monocyte to high-density lipoprotein cholesterol ratio (MHR) and the neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio in predicting certain diseases [16, 17]. Moreover, NHR exhibited great predictive accuracy in hypertension, stroke and cardiovascular risk [18, 19]. As inflammation and lipid disorders are important key features of diabetes, it is of clinical relevance to explore the role of NHR in diabetes and predicting its adverse outcomes.

To address this knowledge gap, we aimed to assess the association of NHR with diabetes and with all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in diabetic participants, using data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES).

sec.title: Study population
sec.p:
The NHANES, organized by the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS), is a nationwide program designed to collect comprehensive health and nutrition data through a multistage, stratified probability sampling method [20]. This ongoing surveillance program offers insights into the health status of adults and children in the United States. Ethical approval for the study was granted by the NCHS Ethics Review Committee, and all participants provided written informed consent. Data from ten NHANES cycles (1999–2018) were analyzed. Participants under 18 years, those lacking data for NHR calculation, or missing mortality information were excluded, resulting in a final sample of 52,428 individuals for examining the association between NHR and diabetes risk. Additionally, a subset of 8,114 participants with pre-existing diabetes were analyzed to explore the relationship between NHR and mortality outcomes, including all-cause and CVD mortality (Fig. 1).Fig. 1
Flowchart for selecting the participants for analysis

sec.title: Assessment of NHR, diabetes and mortality
sec.p: Blood samples were collected at NHANES mobile examination centers following standardized protocols. Neutrophil counts were measured using a Beckman Coulter DxH 800 analyzer, which utilizes multiparameter flow cytometry technology. HDL-C levels were enzymatically quantified using Roche analyzers. All measurements followed standardized NHANES laboratory protocols, ensuring methodological consistency and reproducibility. NHR was calculated as the ratio of absolute neutrophil count (1000 cells/μL) to HDL-C concentration (mg/dL), as per established methods [17]. Diabetes diagnosis was based on the 2021 American Diabetes Association (ADA) diagnostic criteria [21], defined by meeting any of the following: (1) self-reported physician-diagnosed diabetes (ascertained through affirmative response to the question:"Has a doctor ever told you that you have diabetes?"); (2) current use of diabetes medications; (3) fasting plasma glucose ≥ 7.0 mmol/L (126 mg/dL); (4) HbA1c ≥ 6.5% (48 mmol/mol); or (5) 2-h plasma glucose ≥ 11.1 mmol/L (200 mg/dL) during an oral glucose tolerance test.

sec.title: Mortality ascertainment
sec.p: Mortality data, encompassing all-cause and CVD-specific deaths for individuals with diabetes, were linked to the National Death Index and verified through death certificates up to December 31, 2019. CVD-related deaths were classified using ICD-10 codes for heart and cerebrovascular diseases (I00–I09, I11, I13, I20–I51, I60–I69) [22]. The follow-up period spanned from the baseline examination date to the date of death or December 31, 2019, whichever occurred first.

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: The study included sociodemographic and health-related covariates such as sex, age, race, marital status, poverty-to-income ratio (PIR), education level, alcohol consumption, smoking, physical activity, body mass index (BMI), and comorbid conditions. Race categories were non-Hispanic White, Mexican American, non-Hispanic Black, and others. BMI was categorized based on established clinical cutoff values (< 25 kg/m2, 25–30 kg/m2, ≥ 30 kg/m2). Educational attainment was grouped as less than high school versus high school graduate or higher. PIR ≤ 1.3 indicated poverty [23]. Marital status was categorized as married/cohabiting or unmarried. Smoking history was classified into never, former, or current smokers, while alcohol consumption was considered positive if participants reported drinking more than 12 alcoholic beverages in the past year. Physical activity levels were categorized as inactive, moderate, vigorous, or both moderate and vigorous. Insulin resistance was assessed using the homeostasis model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), calculated as: HOMA-IR = (fasting blood glucose [mmol/L] × fasting serum insulin [μU/mL])/22.5 [24]. A HOMA-IR value > 2.6 was considered indicative of insulin resistance, as previously reported [25]. Statin and anti-diabetic medication use was determined based on self-reported prescription medications. Hypertension was defined by self-reported diagnosis, use of antihypertensive drugs, or blood pressure measurements (systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg). Stroke and heart failure history were based on self-reported physician diagnoses.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Weighted logistic regression models were employed to evaluate the association between NHR and diabetes risk. Two hierarchical models were constructed: 1) a partially adjusted model controlling for age and sex, and 2) a fully adjusted model that additionally incorporated established diabetes determinants and potential confounders identified from prior literature, including race/ethnicity, marital status, educational attainment, BMI, PIR, smoking status, alcohol consumption, physical activity level, HOMA-IR, use of glucose-lowering medications, statin use, and history of hypertension, stroke, and heart failure [4, 5, 8, 25]. Trend analysis treated NHR tertile medians as continuous variables. For diabetes-related mortality, weighted Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% confidence intervals. Restricted cubic splines were performed to evaluate dose–response relationships between NHR and diabetes or mortality outcomes, adjusting for covariates.

Stratified analyses were conducted to assess potential effect modification by variables such as age, sex, race, education level, PIR categories, smoking, alcohol consumption, statin use, and physical activity. Interaction significance was evaluated using likelihood ratio tests, comparing models with and without interaction terms. To ensure the robustness of our findings, we performed several sensitivity analyses. First, we restricted analyses to participants with fasting glucose measurements. Second, we conducted complete-case analyses by excluding individuals with missing covariate data. Third, to address potential selection bias from complete-case exclusion, we additionally implemented multiple imputation approaches to handle missing data. Fourth, to address potential reverse causation, we repeated mortality analyses after excluding deaths that occurred within the first two years of follow-up. All statistical analyses were carried out using R software (version 4.2.3, http://www.r-project.org/), with statistical significance defined as a two-sided P value < 0.05.

sec.title: Baseline characteristics according to tertiles of NHR
sec.p: The average age of participants was 47.51 ± 19.23 years, with 25,413 (48.47%) being men, 10,224 (19.50%) current smokers, and 20,691 (39.47%) diagnosed with hypertension (Table 1). The population was divided into three groups based on baseline NHR tertiles (Table 1). Participants with higher NHR values were generally younger, more likely to be male, white, current smokers, and drinkers, and had higher rates of hypertension, stroke, and heart failure. They also demonstrated lower education levels, and PIR, but higher physical activity levels (all P < 0.001).

sec.title: Association between NHR and risk of diabetes
sec.p:
Participants with diabetes were more likely to be older, less educated, have a higher PIR and BMI, engage in less physical activity, and exhibit more severe insulin resistance. Notably, they had significantly higher NHR levels (4.02 ± 2.04 vs. 3.38 ± 1.98, P < 0.001) (Supplemental Table 1). Table 2 summarizes the associations between NHR and diabetes across three models. In the multivariable analysis treating NHR as a continuous variable, a 1-unit increase in NHR was associated with a 17% higher likelihood of diabetes after adjusting for potential confounders (OR, 1.17 [95% CI, 1.13–1.21]). Similar results were observed when participants were grouped by NHR tertiles, with the highest diabetes risk found in the top tertile (all P < 0.001, Table 2). In the fully adjusted model, the ORs (95% CIs) for diabetes were 1.30 (1.12–1.51) and 2.08 (1.76–2.47) for the second and third tertiles, respectively, compared to the first tertile (model 3, Table 2). Restricted cubic splines indicated a non-linear relationship between NHR and risk of diabetes (non-linear P < 0.001, Fig. 2A). Table 2

sec.title: Association of NHR with all-cause and CVD mortality in diabetes
sec.p:
During a median (interquartile range) follow-up of 9.42 (5.08–14.33) years, 2288 incident all-cause deaths (28.2%) and 785 (9.67%) CVD deaths were observed. Table 3 shows that elevated NHR was significantly associated with higher risks of all-cause mortality (HR, 1.07; 95% CI, 1.04–1.11) and cardiovascular mortality (HR, 1.08; 95% CI, 1.04–1.13) in individuals with diabetes after full adjustment. When stratified by sex, we observed that the elevated NHR had greater impact on the risk of all-cause and CVD mortality in women with diabetes (Table 3). The restricted cubic splines further showed that NHR was nearly linearly associated with risk of all-cause or CVD mortality (both P for overall < 0.001, Fig. 2B-C). Table 3

sec.title: Stratified and sensitivity analyses
sec.p:
Stratified analyses revealed that the association between NHR and diabetes risk was more pronounced in female, White participants aged ≥ 50 years or former smokers (all P for interaction < 0.05; Fig. 3). When stratified by education level, PIR categories, drinking status, statin use, and physical activity levels, the association remained consistent (all P for interactions > 0.05; Fig. 3). Sensitivity analyses consistently supported these findings: the association remained significant when excluding participants lacking fasting blood glucose measurements (Supplemental Table 2), when restricting to complete cases (Supplemental Table 3), and when applying multiple imputation for missing data (Supplemental Table 4). Similarly, the relationship between NHR and the risk of all-cause or cardiovascular mortality in individuals with diabetes was robust when deaths within the first two years of follow-up were excluded (Supplemental Table 5).Fig. 3
Subgroup analysis of the association between baseline neutrophil-to-high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol ratio and diabetes. Weighted logistic regression was performed after adjustment for sex, age, race, marital status, education level, body mass index categories, PIR categories, smoking status, drinking status, anti-diabetic drug use, statin use, insulin resistance, physical activity, hypertension, stroke, and heart failure, except for the stratification variable itself

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this prospective cohort of U.S. population, we demonstrate that elevated NHR is related to an increased risk of diabetes, and with the risk of diabetes-related all-cause and CVD mortality. A series of stratifications and sensitivity analyses confirmed the robustness of our findings. These findings suggested a potential role for monitoring NHR levels in the management of diabetes and its adverse outcomes.

In recent years, complex hematological predictors have gained prominence in clinical practice. Markers such as the MHR [27], systemic immune-inflammatory index [28], and triglyceride glucose index [29] have been employed to assess diabetes risk and its complications, highlighting the critical role of inflammation and lipid metabolism in diabetes development. NHR, a novel composite indicator derived from peripheral blood neutrophil count and HDL-C levels [30], provides a unique advantage by simultaneously capturing the interplay between lipid metabolism and inflammatory pathways, as well as the interaction between HDL-C and neutrophils [31]. We, for the first time, demonstrated that elevated NHR with risk of diabetes after adjustment for potential confounders, suggesting its novel role in the pathogenesis of diabetes. Inflammation (increased neutrophils) and dyslipidemia (low HDL-C) are two important pathological processes that initiate and promote atherosclerotic CVD [32, 33]. Previous studies revealed the predictive role of NHR in early renal dysfunction and albuminuria and risk of diabetic kidney disease among diabetic patients [34, 35]. A recent post hoc analysis of Kailuan cohort study further showed that pre-diabetic participants with high NHR levels tended to have greater adverse cardiovascular outcomes [36]. Based on previous results, we further demonstrate that NHR may be an effective marker for future death from all causes and CVD in the diabetic population. With further validation in large-scale cohorts, integrating NHR levels into routine diabetes screening parameters—including fasting glucose and HbA1c measurements—could potentially enhance risk stratification for both suspected and confirmed diabetic patients in clinical practice.

Another notable finding of our study was the significant interaction between the association of NHR and diabetes risk with age, sex, ethnicity and smoking status. We hypothesize that in individuals with stronger risk factors, such as Mexican American and smoking, the role of NHR may be overshadowed, as these conditions are already strongly predisposed to diabetes development [37, 38]. Interestingly, NHR demonstrated a stronger predictive ability for all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in women with diabetes compared to men. These results suggest that monitoring and controlling NHR could offer additional benefits in reducing diabetes risk and its adverse outcomes, even in individuals without traditional risk factors. Although missing covariates or early deaths could potentially confound the findings, our sensitivity analyses confirmed the robustness of the association by including only participants with complete data or excluding deaths that occurred within the first two years of follow-up.

Several potential biological mechanisms may explain how NHR affect diabetes risk and its adverse cardiovascular outcomes, even if the precise processes underlying this correlation are still unclear. Higher glycemia and dysfunctional HDL-C in diabetes are closely associated with the severity of inflammatory responses and the risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality [8–11]. First, the NHR can not only present both inflammatory state and lipid metabolism, but also indicate the interaction between neutrophils and HDL-C. The neutrophil burden is elevated in diabetic patients with advanced atherosclerotic plaques, conferring a higher risk of cardiovascular mortality. Low HDL-C has also been shown to significantly accelerate atherosclerosis in diabetic patients [39]. Second, chronic exposure to hyperglycemia, in conjunction with dyslipidemia and persistent subclinical inflammation, drives the pathophysiological progression of macrovascular complications in diabetes [40]. Abnormal glycemic levels promote oxidative stress and excessive free radical accumulation in endothelial cells. This triggers multiple inflammatory pathways, leading to vasoconstriction and enhanced platelet adhesion [41]. Furthermore, as the predominant leukocyte subset, neutrophils serve as more sensitive biomarkers of CVD risk compared to monocytes and lymphocytes [8, 9]. Thus, these mechanisms may support NHR's predictive utility for diabetes risk and its related mortality.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: This study has several notable strengths: first, NHANES includes large and representative sample size of U.S. population. Second, comprehensive adjustments for confounding factors and extensive sensitivity analyses were performed, enhancing the reliability of the results. Third, NHR, derived from routine blood tests and biochemical analyses, is both cost-effective and easily accessible, making it a promising tool for diabetes prediction and management. Its potential warrants further in-depth investigation.

However, several limitations need to be highlighted. First, identifying diabetes through questionnaires may introduce recall bias, or recording errors. Some asymptomatic diabetic population who did not have blood tests may be missed. Second, although we carefully adjusted for known risk factors, residual confounding may persist due to unmeasured variables including diabetes duration and severity, medication adherence, dietary patterns, and genetic predisposition, which could potentially influence the observed associations. Third, this post hoc analysis was based on U.S. population, and its applicability to other ethnic populations cannot be directly inferred. Finally, the current analysis is observational, and causality cannot be inferred from the associations observed.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In conclusion, we demonstrated the NHR was positively associated with the risk of diabetes and all-cause and CVD mortality in diabetic patients. Further studies are warranted to validate its clinical application in diabetes management.

Neutrophil to high-density lipoprotein cholesterol ratio

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors express their gratitude to the NHANES database for their uploading valuable datasets.

notes.title: Authors' contributions
notes.p: Y.T.: conceptualization, methodology, data curation, software, writing – original draft. Y.L.: data curation, visualization, software. S.G.: writing–methodology. C.D.: conceptualization, funding acquisition, methodology, writing –review & editing, supervision.

sec.title: Institutional review board statement
sec.p: There was no requirement for institutional review board permission since the NHANES database was open to the public.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This research received no external funding.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: In this study, publicly accessible datasets were examined. These data can be found here: (https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/analyticguidelines.aspx, Accessed on 1 September 2023).

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: This study was reviewed and approved by the NCHS Ethics Review Board in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. The patients/participants provided written informed consent to participate in this study.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
